facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 218 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 218 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and order dated September 8, 1959 of Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No.354 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated September 8, 1959, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No.354 of 1959.

facts.text: Narain Singh and his three nephews Mehar Singh, Mewa Singh and Pakhar Singh tried before Court of Session, Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: Narain Singh and his three nephews-Mehar Singh, Mewa Singh and Pakhar Singh-were tried before the Court of Session, Ludhiana for offences punishable under s. 302 read with s. 34.

facts.text: On October 31, 1958, Narain Singh and nephews irrigating their field when Bachan Singh diverted water.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that in the evening of October 31, 1958, when Narain Singh and his three nephews were irrigating their field, Bachan Singh diverted the flow of water into his own filed.

facts.text: Quarrel between Narain Singh, nephews and Bachan Singh on October 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Narain Singh and his nephews were thereupon enraged, and there was a quarrel between them and Bachan Singh.

facts.text: Narain Singh and nephews attacked Bachan Singh with weapons causing serious injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Narain Singh and his nephews made an attack upon Bachan Singh with a kaholi, caused him serious injuries.

facts.text: Mehar Singh armed with spear, Pakhar Singh with Kaholi, Mewa Singh with salang, Narain Singh with stick according to prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution, Mehar Singh at the time of the assault was armed with a spear, Pakhar Singh with a Kaholi, Mewa Singh with a salang and Narain Singh with a stick.

facts.text: Complaint lodged about assault with police, Bachan Singh removed to Civil Hospital, Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: A Complaint was lodged about the assault with the Notice, and Bachan Singh was removed to the Civil Hospital, Ludhiana.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector recorded statement of Bachan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Inspector of Police investigating the case recorded the statement of Bachan Singh,

facts.text: First Class Magistrate of Ludhiana recorded declaration of Bachan Singh on evening of November 2, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and a First Class Magistrate of Ludhiana recorded his declaration on the evening of November 2, 1958.

facts.text: Bachan Singh died on November 3, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Bachan Singh died on November 3, 1958.

facts.text: Narain Singh pleaded right of self defence, claimed Bachan Singh threw him down and attempted to strangulate him.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, Narain Singh-pleaded that he bad acted in exercise of the right of self defence and had caused injuries to Bachan Singh because the latter had thrown him down and had attempted to strangulate him.

facts.text: Narain Singh was wearing small kirpan and used it in self defence.

anchor.surface_text: I was then wearing small kirpan. I unsheathed it and used it in self defence causing a companyple of injuries to the deceased

facts.text: Pakhar Singh and Mewa Singh denied presence at scene.

anchor.surface_text: Pakhar Singh and Mews Singh denied their presence at the scene of offence.

facts.text: Mehar Singh claimed he intervened to separate, was unarmed.

anchor.surface_text: Mehar Singh claimed that he was present at the scene, and he had tried to intervene and separate Bachan Singh and Narain Singh.

facts.text: Narain Singh had six contused injuries, Mehar Singh had one incised injury and four abraded contusions.

anchor.surface_text: Narain Singh had six companytused injuries and Mehr Singh had one incised injury and four abraded companytusions.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted Mewa Singh, Mehar Singh and Pakhar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge accordingly acquitted Mewa Singh, , Mehar Singh and Pakhar Singh of the offence charged

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted Narain Singh under s.304 Part II IPC, sentenced to 5 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: and companyvicted Narain Singh of the offence punishable under a. 304 Part Tr of the Indian Penal  ode and sentenced him to suffer rigorous imprisonment for five years.

facts.text: Punjab High Court reduced sentence to 3 years RI, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, reduced the sentence imposed upon Narain Singh to rigorous imprisonment for 3 years and subject to that modification dismissed the appeal

facts.text: Supreme Court acquitted Narain Singh of offence under s.304 Part II IPC.

anchor.surface_text: After arguments were companycluded in this appeal we ordered that the appellant Narain Singh be acquitted of the offence under s. 304 Part II of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Bachan Singh had four incised injuries: three on chest, one on ring finger left side.

anchor.surface_text: Bachan Singh had four incised injuries on his person, three on the cheat, and the fourth on the ,,ring finger left side.

facts.text: Incised injuries could be caused by spear or kirpan, not salang or kaholi.

anchor.surface_text: None of these injuries companyld be caused with a salang or a kaholi the incised injuries companyld be caused by a spear and also by kirpan.

facts.text: Two dying declarations of Bachan Singh tendered in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Two statements of Bachan Singh which were in view of his death admissible as dying declarations-one recorded by the Investigating Officer and the other by the First Class Magistrate, Ludhiana-were also tendered in evidence.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held prosecution evidence unreliable for murder charge against nephews.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore in the view of the Sessions Judge the oral and other evidence was insufficient to sustain the charge of .murder against the three nephews of Narain Singh.

concepts.interpretation: Statement under s.342 must be considered in entirety; cannot dissect to use incriminatory parts divorced from explanation; can convict on confession but not partial admission without prosecution proof.

issues.text: Whether the courts can rely on the statement of the accused under s.342 CrPC by dissecting it and using only incriminatory parts divorced from the explanation
Whether the burden of proving the exception of self-defence lies upon the accused where the prosecution has failed to establish the basic offence

anchor.surface_text: Therefore in the view of the Sessions Judge the oral and other evidence was insufficient to sustain the charge of .murder against the three nephews of Narain Singh. arguments.claim: Court cannot dissect s.342 statement and use only incriminatory parts divorced from explanation
Prosecution failed to prove offence by reliable evidence, so no burden on accused to prove self-defence exception
Strangulation attempt creates reasonable apprehension justifying causing death in self-defence

anchor.surface_text: Narain Singh admitted that he had caused injuries to Bachan Singh with a Kirpan carried by him, but he explained that lie caused the injuries when he was thrown down and Bhchan Singh was attempting to strangulate him. There can be numberdoubt that if a person reasonably apprehends that his assailant is attempting to strangulate him, exercise of the right of defence of person extends even to causing death of the assailant.

arguments.claim: Incised injuries on Bachan could be caused by kirpan, not salang or kaholi

anchor.surface_text: None of these injuries companyld be caused with a salang or a kaholi the incised injuries companyld be caused by a spear and also by kirpan.

arguments.court_reasoning: Consistent with petitioner's kirpan use in self-defence

holdings.text: Narain Singh had not exceeded the right of self-defence by causing the death of Bachan Singh.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission in s.342 statement considered in entirety; strangulation attempt created reasonable apprehension of death justifying lethal force in self-defence.

holdings.text: It is not open to the Court to dissect the statement under s.342 CrPC and pick out incriminative parts divorced from the explanation given by the accused.

anchor.surface_text: Under s.342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure... the statement of the accused can only be taken into consideration in its entirety. It is not open to the Court to dissect the statement and to pick out a part of the statement which may be incriminative, and then to examine whether the explanation furnished by the accused for his conduct is supported by the evidence on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.342 examination enables accused to explain prosecution evidence; entire statement must be considered, not selective incriminatory portions.

holdings.text: Burden of proving exception like self-defence lies on accused only if prosecution first establishes prima facie guilt of the offence charged.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution failed to prove offence by reliable evidence, so no burden shifts to accused on exception.

holdings.text: Prosecution evidence insufficient to sustain charge of murder under s.302 r/w s.34 IPC against Narain Singh and nephews.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore in the view of the Sessions Judge the oral and other evidence was insufficient to sustain the charge of murder against the three nephews of Narain Singh... The High Court agreed with the view of the Sessions Court that the evidence was insufficient to establish the case for the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral testimony unreliable with variations; dying declarations unreliable due to consultation opportunity and no explanation for accused injuries; medical evidence consistent only with kirpan, not prosecution weapons.

holdings.text: Injuries on Bachan Singh caused by Narain Singh with kirpan; nephews did not participate.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Courts injuries on the person of Bachan Singh were caused by Narain Singh by striking him with a kirpan, and the three nephews of Narain Singh had not participated in the assault.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Medical evidence shows incised wounds possible by kirpan or spear, not salang/kaholi; prosecution eyewitnesses unreliable; consistent with Narain's statement.

holdings.text: Appellant Narain Singh acquitted of offence under s.304 Part II IPC; conviction and sentence set aside.

anchor.surface_text: After arguments were concluded in this appeal we ordered that the appellant Narain Singh be acquitted of the offence under s. 304 Part II of the Indian Penal Code of which he was convicted and the sentence passed on him be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Self-defence plea justified act; no prosecution case proved; s.342 statement supports defence.
